edges.description: Trans-West African Coastal Highway segment, Lagos-Cotonou. Major paved highway, heavy truck traffic.
Trans-West African Coastal Highway segment, Cotonou-Lome. Well-maintained coastal road.
Trans-West African Coastal Highway segment, Lome-Accra. Paved two-lane highway with border crossing at Aflao.
Trans-West African Coastal Highway segment, Accra-Abidjan via Takoradi and border at Elubo-Noe.
Lagos-Ibadan Expressway. Nigeria's busiest highway, recently rehabilitated. Six lanes.
A2 highway via Lokoja. Major north-south trunk road, partially dual carriageway.
A2 highway, Abuja-Kaduna-Kano. Nigeria's primary northern corridor, recently upgraded.
Lagos-Ore-Benin City-Port Harcourt highway. Major route through Niger Delta region, variable road quality.
Trans-Saharan corridor, Kano-Niamey via Maradi. Paved but poorly maintained in sections, heavy informal trade traffic.
Kano-Zinder road via Katsina border crossing. Important cross-border corridor, secondary road quality.
RN5 Niamey-Ouagadougou. Main east-west Sahelian corridor, paved but with deteriorating sections.
RN1 Ouagadougou-Bobo Dioulasso-Bamako corridor. Paved, single carriageway with checkpoints.
RN1 Ouagadougou-Bobo Dioulasso. Burkina Faso's primary highway, well-maintained.
Abidjan-Ouagadougou corridor via Bouake and Ferkessedougou. Primary trade and transit route for landlocked Burkina Faso.
A3 autoroute Abidjan-Bouake (Yamoussoukro). Cote d'Ivoire's primary north-south highway, excellent quality.
A3 autoroute Abidjan-Yamoussoukro. Modern dual carriageway connecting economic and political capitals.
Bouake-Yamoussoukro highway. Well-maintained internal connection.
N6 Accra-Kumasi highway. Ghana's busiest internal corridor, recently expanded sections.
N10 Kumasi-Tamale. North-south link through the transition zone, single carriageway.
Accra-Tema motorway. Short modern highway connecting capital to main industrial port.
Autoroute a peage Dakar-Thies. Modern toll highway, recently constructed.
RN2 Thies-Saint-Louis via Louga. Paved national road in fair condition.
Dakar-Bamako corridor (road and partially operational railway). Historic rail link, road alternative via Tambacounda and Kayes.
Trans-Gambia Highway via Kaolack and ferry crossing. Route complicated by Gambian territory bisecting Senegal.
RN2 via Saint-Louis and Rosso border crossing. Paved road with ferry crossing at the Senegal River.
RN7 Bamako-Sikasso. Southern Mali highway to Cote d'Ivoire border, paved.
RN6 Bamako-Segou-Mopti. Northern route, security concerns in Mopti region. Road quality variable.
Bamako-Conakry via Kankan corridor. Important outlet to the sea for landlocked Mali, road partially unpaved.
RN1 Conakry-Kankan via Mamou and Faranah. Guinea's main internal highway, variable condition.
Conakry-Freetown via Kambia border crossing. Coastal route, portions in poor condition.
Freetown-Bo highway. Sierra Leone's main internal route, recently rehabilitated.
Freetown-Monrovia via Bo and Kenema. Mano River corridor, poorly maintained, sections unpaved.
Conakry-Bissau coastal route via Boke. Secondary road, partially unpaved.
Dakar-Ziguinchor-Bissau route. Road via Casamance region, ferry crossing required.
RN1 Niamey-Zinder via Maradi. Niger's main east-west highway (Route de l'Unite), paved.
RN25 Zinder-Agadez. Trans-Saharan route heading north, paved but deteriorating, security issues.
Niamey-Bamako via Ouagadougou. Indirect overland route through Burkina Faso.
RN1 Lome-Kara. Togo's main north-south highway, paved single carriageway.
RNIE1 Cotonou-Porto-Novo. Short paved highway connecting economic and administrative capitals of Benin.
Tamale-Bolgatanga-Ouagadougou. Northern Ghana to Burkina Faso corridor via Paga border.
Sikasso-Bobo Dioulasso cross-border route. Important Malian-Burkinabe connection.
Abidjan-San Pedro-Harper-Monrovia coastal route. Variable quality, sections under construction.
Kara-Dapaong-Ouagadougou. Northern Togo to Burkina Faso via Cinkanse border.
Lagos-Calabar-Douala corridor via southeastern Nigeria. Includes ferry crossing at Calabar.
Kankan-Kouremale-Bamako. Guinea-Mali cross-border route, partially unpaved.
Lagos-Ibadan-Abuja-Kano full north-south corridor. Nigeria's backbone highway system.
Tema port-Lome port coastal connector. Key port-to-port trade route.
Nigeria-Ghana primary trade corridor. Petroleum products, manufactured goods, food. ECOWAS CET applies.
Lagos-Tema port-to-port maritime trade. Containerized goods, vehicles, machinery.
Nigeria-Cote d'Ivoire bilateral trade. Petroleum exports, cocoa/agricultural imports.
Nigeria-Benin trade corridor. Massive informal re-export trade in addition to formal trade. Cotonou port as entry point for Nigerian market.
Cote d'Ivoire-Burkina Faso trade axis. Abidjan port serves as Burkina's primary maritime outlet. Petroleum, consumer goods, agricultural exports.
Cote d'Ivoire-Mali trade. Abidjan serves as primary port for landlocked Mali. Fuel, manufactured goods.
Nigeria-Niger trade corridor. Food staples, manufactured goods southbound; livestock, onions northbound.
Kano-Zinder cross-border trade. Significant informal trade in foodstuffs and consumer goods.
Senegal-Mali trade. Dakar port as alternative outlet for Malian trade. Petroleum products, construction materials.
Ghana-Togo bilateral trade. Consumer goods, agricultural products. Cross-border smuggling significant.
Ghana-Burkina Faso trade via Tema port. Tema as alternative port for Burkinabe imports.
Nigeria-Cameroon bilateral trade. Cross-ECOWAS/CEMAC tariff barrier applies. Petroleum, manufactured goods.
Morocco-Nigeria trade. Phosphates, manufactured goods, banking services. Growing trade under AfCFTA.
Morocco-Senegal trade axis. Strong historical and commercial ties. Fish, phosphates, manufactured goods.
Morocco-Cote d'Ivoire trade. Banking, construction, phosphates. Moroccan investment hub.
Intra-UEMOA/CFA trade between Cote d'Ivoire and Senegal. Shared currency facilitates transactions.
Benin-Togo bilateral trade. Both serve as re-export hubs for larger neighbours. CFA zone trade.
Benin-Niger trade via Parakou and Malanville. Cotonou port serves parts of Niger's import needs.
Togo-Burkina Faso corridor. Lome port as additional outlet for Burkinabe trade. CFA zone.
Cote d'Ivoire-Guinea trade. Manufactured goods, agricultural products. Growing corridor.
Senegal-Gambia trade. Groundnuts, fish, consumer goods. Complicated by Gambian re-export trade.
Senegal-Mauritania trade. Fish, livestock, construction materials. Cross-ECOWAS tariff applies.
Senegal-Guinea-Bissau trade. Cashews, fish, consumer goods. UEMOA shared currency.
Port Harcourt-Douala port-to-port trade. Oil services, manufactured goods. Cross-bloc tariff.
Ghana-Cote d'Ivoire bilateral trade. Cocoa, petroleum, manufactured goods. Two largest coastal economies.
Burkina Faso-Niger bilateral trade. Livestock, agricultural goods. CFA zone, shared Sahelian economy.
Mali-Guinea trade. Conakry port as alternative maritime outlet for Mali. Fuel, construction materials.
Nigeria-Senegal maritime trade. Growing bilateral commercial ties within ECOWAS.
Morocco-Ghana trade. Phosphates, banking, manufacturing. Moroccan companies expanding into Ghana.
Morocco-Mauritania trade. Fish, minerals, manufactured goods. Trans-Saharan commerce.
Southern Mali agricultural trade through Cote d'Ivoire. Cotton, mangoes, livestock.
Togo-Niger trade corridor via northern Togo and Burkina Faso. Lome port serving Nigerien imports.
Sierra Leone-Guinea bilateral trade. Mano River Union members. Agricultural products, mining supplies.
Nigerian diaspora in Ghana. Traders, students, professionals. Second largest West African migration corridor.
Burkinabe migration to Cote d'Ivoire. Largest migration corridor in West Africa. Cocoa plantation labour, urban employment.
Malian migration to Cote d'Ivoire. Agricultural labour, urban informal sector. Historical pattern since colonial era.
Nigerien seasonal and permanent migration to northern Nigeria. Cross-Hausa ethnic ties facilitate movement.
Zinder-Kano migration. Short-distance, often seasonal. Shared Hausa culture facilitates integration.
Guinean migration to Senegal. Political refugees and economic migrants. Dakar as regional hub.
Senegalese-Gambian cross-border movement. Shared Wolof and Mandinka communities, family ties.
Ghanaian migration to Nigeria. Professionals, traders, entertainment industry workers.
Malian migration to Senegal. Trade diaspora, seasonal workers, students. Historical Dakar-Bamako corridor.
Togolese migration to Ghana. Short-distance cross-border movement. Ewe ethnic group spans border.
Beninese migration to Nigeria. Massive cross-border movement, Yoruba shared identity. Daily commuters and permanent migrants.
Southern Burkina Faso to Cote d'Ivoire migration. Agricultural labour in cocoa and coffee plantations.
Guinea-Sierra Leone cross-border movement. Mano River Union facilitates. Refugee flows during crises.
Liberian migration to Cote d'Ivoire. Conflict-displaced and economic migrants. Dan/Yacouba shared ethnicity.
Southern Mali (Sikasso region) to Cote d'Ivoire. Agricultural labour migration, especially during cocoa harvest.
Burkinabe migration to Ghana. Alternative to Cote d'Ivoire corridor. Labour and trade migrants.
Internal Niger migration and transit. Agadez as transit hub for trans-Saharan migration routes.
Guinean migration to Mali. Cross-border Malinke/Mandinka movement. Trade and seasonal labour.
Guinea-Bissau to Senegal migration. Political instability push factor. Shared ethnic groups (Mandinka, Jola).
Cape Verdean migration to Senegal. Maritime route. Cape Verdean diaspora concentrated in Dakar.
Mauritania-Senegal migration. Cross-Senegal River movement. Shared Fulani/Pulaar communities.
Francophone cultural axis. Shared French language, Mandinka heritage, Sufi Islamic brotherhood (Tijaniyya). Deep musical exchange.
Sahelian Francophone cultural corridor. Shared French, FESPACO film festival in Ouagadougou, cross-border Mossi-Bambara exchange.
Francophone north-south cultural corridor. Abidjan as cultural capital, Ouagadougou as cinema capital (FESPACO). Shared CFA franc zone.
Coastal Francophone cultural connection. Shared French language, Coupe-Decale/Afrobeats exchange.
Benin-Togo deep cultural ties. Shared Ewe/Fon ethnic heritage, Vodun religious tradition, Francophone.
Francophone Sahel-coast cultural link. Shared French language and UEMOA institutional culture.
Senegal-Mauritania cultural ties. Shared Pulaar/Fulani communities along Senegal River. Islamic scholarly tradition.
Anglophone West Africa cultural axis. Nollywood-Ghallywood exchange, shared English, Afrobeats music scene.
Anglophone cultural connection. Shared English, Krio-influenced pidgin, similar colonial heritage.
Sierra Leone-Liberia cultural bond. Shared English, Krio/Liberian English, Mano River Union identity, post-conflict solidarity.
Anglophone West Africa. Shared English, pan-African historical ties (Liberian-Ghanaian relations), ECOWAS cultural programmes.
Anglophone cultural connection. Shared English language, similar educational systems, Commonwealth membership.
Hausa cultural corridor. Shared Hausa language and ethnicity spanning the Nigeria-Niger border. Hausa literary and Islamic scholarly tradition.
Core Hausa heartland. Deep shared Hausa identity, Tijaniyya and Qadiriyya Sufi orders, pre-colonial Hausa city-state heritage.
Yoruba cultural corridor. Shared Yoruba language, Orisha/Vodun religious heritage, Gelede masquerade tradition spanning Nigeria-Benin.
Yoruba heartland connection. Ibadan as historical Yoruba capital, shared Yoruba language, deep kinship ties.
Yoruba cross-border heritage. Porto-Novo founded by Yoruba (Gun subgroup). Shared masquerade traditions and festivals.
Mandinka/Manding cultural corridor. Shared Manding heritage, griot tradition, kora music. French language bond.
Mandinka heartland. Kankan and Bamako as core Manding cultural centres. Shared language, Sufi Islamic practice, oral history tradition.
Mandinka-Jola-Wolof cultural exchange. Banjul's Mandinka population with ties to Malian Manding heartland. Shared kora tradition.
Mandinka corridor via Casamance. Shared Mandinka heritage, similar musical traditions (balafon, kora).
Lusophone cultural bond. Shared Portuguese language, Crioulo lingua franca, colonial heritage, CPLP membership.
Francophone West Africa's two cultural capitals. Shared French, coup-dcal/mbalax music exchange, fashion, Francophone literary tradition.
Sahelian Francophone bond. Shared French, Hausa/Zarma cross-border communities, Alliance of Sahel States cultural solidarity.
Ewe cultural corridor. Shared Ewe ethnicity spanning Ghana-Togo border. Annual Hogbetsotso festival, shared drumming traditions.
UEMOA/BCEAO axis. Shared CFA franc (West African), zero forex cost, common central bank. Two largest UEMOA economies.
UEMOA shared currency zone. CFA franc eliminates exchange risk. Abidjan as UEMOA financial centre (BRVM stock exchange).
UEMOA financial corridor. Shared CFA franc, BRVM accessible from Bamako. Mali's primary financial link to global markets.
UEMOA monetary zone. Shared CFA franc. Major remittance corridor with established money transfer networks.
UEMOA CFA franc zone. Seamless financial transactions, shared BCEAO monetary policy.
UEMOA financial link. Shared CFA franc, BRVM listed companies accessible from both markets.
UEMOA monetary zone. CFA franc shared currency, BCEAO central banking supervision.
UEMOA shared currency. Guinea-Bissau joined CFA franc zone in 1997. Dakar as banking hub for Bissau.
UEMOA twin port cities. Shared CFA franc, competing as re-export financial hubs.
UEMOA Sahelian financial axis. Shared CFA franc, Alliance of Sahel States exploring monetary alternatives.
Two largest non-CFA financial centres. Nigerian banks (UBA, Access, GT Bank) have major Ghanaian operations. Forex risk (Naira-Cedi).
Cross-currency financial corridor. Nigerian bank branches in Abidjan, Ecobank (Togo-based) bridges both zones.
Morocco as Africa's banking gateway. Attijariwafa, BMCE Bank of Africa with Nigerian operations. Casablanca Finance City.
Moroccan banking expansion into Francophone West Africa. Attijariwafa, BMCE present in Senegal. Insurance and microfinance.
Morocco-Cote d'Ivoire financial axis. Moroccan banks among largest in Abidjan. Investment in real estate, infrastructure.
Cross-monetary-zone financial corridor. Nigerian bank (UBA, GT Bank) expansion into Senegal. Ecobank bridging both.
Non-CFA Anglophone financial link. GT Bank, Ecobank present in both. Mobile money interoperability efforts.
Nigeria-Ghana political axis. Two ECOWAS anchors (largest economy and seat of ECOWAS Commission). Frequent bilateral summits.
Nigeria-Senegal ECOWAS political corridor. Coordinated diplomatic positions. Abuja as ECOWAS headquarters city.
Nigeria-Niger bilateral. Strained since 2023 coup. ECOWAS sanctions regime. Border security cooperation on Boko Haram.
Alliance of Sahel States (AES). Post-coup military governments. Mutual defense pact. Suspended from ECOWAS. Deep political alignment.
Alliance of Sahel States (AES) founding members. Anti-French, pro-sovereignty alignment. Joint counterterrorism operations.
Alliance of Sahel States core. Military government solidarity. Shared ECOWAS suspension. Exploring CFA franc exit.
Nigeria-Cote d'Ivoire political relations. ECOWAS co-leadership on Sahel crisis response. Bilateral cooperation.
Ghana-Cote d'Ivoire bilateral. Cocoa Producers Alliance. Shared border and maritime cooperation.
Ghana-Togo bilateral. Immediate neighbours, ECOWAS cooperation. Joint border management initiatives.
Nigeria-Cameroon bilateral. Cross-ECOWAS/CEMAC relationship. Lake Chad Basin Commission. Bakassi Peninsula dispute resolved by ICJ.
Senegal-Gambia political axis. Senegambia confederation legacy. ECOWAS-backed intervention in 2017 crisis. Casamance issue.
Senegal-Mauritania bilateral. 1989 crisis legacy managed. River Senegal Organisation (OMVS) cooperation. Gas field co-development.
Mano River Union members. Guinea-Sierra Leone bilateral cooperation on security, trade, and border management.
Mano River Union. Sierra Leone-Liberia post-conflict peacebuilding cooperation. Shared UN peacekeeping legacy.
Nigeria-Mali relations. Strained since coup and ECOWAS sanctions. Nigeria leads ECOWAS diplomatic efforts.
Morocco-Nigeria strategic partnership. Gas pipeline project (Nigeria-Morocco). African Union dynamics. Two continental powers.
Morocco-Senegal strong bilateral. Morocco's ECOWAS membership bid supported by Senegal. Religious ties (Tijaniyya). OCP phosphate cooperation.
Guinea-Bissau-Senegal bilateral. Senegalese military and political influence. ECOWAS stability efforts. Casamance conflict linkages.
Burkinabe agricultural labour in Cote d'Ivoire. ~1.2M workers. Cocoa, coffee, palm oil plantations. Largest labour flow in West Africa. Remittances ~$400M/year.
Malian labour in Cote d'Ivoire. Agricultural and urban informal sector. Remittances critical for rural Malian households. Volume in thousands of workers.
Nigerian professional labour in Ghana. Telecoms, banking, oil & gas services. Skilled worker migration. Volume in thousands.
Beninese labour in Lagos. Cross-border daily commuters and permanent workers. Informal trade, domestic work, construction. Volume in thousands.
Nigerien labour migration to Lagos. Urban informal sector, construction, domestic work. Remittances vital for Niger economy. Volume in thousands.
Togolese labour in Ghana. Cross-border workers, informal trade, domestic sector. Ewe ethnic ties facilitate. Volume in thousands.
Malian labour in Senegal. Construction, trade, informal sector. Historic migration pattern. Remittances ~$150M/year. Volume in thousands.
Guinean labour in Senegal. Trade diaspora, small business, domestic work. Volume in thousands.
Burkinabe labour in Ghana. Mining sector (Ashanti gold), agriculture, urban services. Alternative to Cote d'Ivoire. Volume in thousands.
Southern Malian agricultural labour in central Cote d'Ivoire. Seasonal cocoa/cotton harvest workers. Cross-border at Zegoua. Volume in thousands.
Ghanaian professional labour in Nigeria. Nollywood, financial services, academia. Reverse brain-drain flow. Volume in thousands.
Upper Guinea labour to Bamako. Gold mining, urban employment. Mandinka network facilitates placement. Volume in thousands.
Southwestern Burkina agricultural labour in Cote d'Ivoire. Seasonal and permanent. Cocoa belt employment. Volume in thousands.
Internal Ghana north-south labour migration. Northern Region youth to Accra for urban employment. Kayayei (head porters). Volume in thousands.
Internal Nigeria north-south labour flow. Hausa traders and workers in Lagos. Almajiri youth. Sabon Gari communities. Volume in thousands.
Cape Verdean labour in Senegal. Maritime sector, trade, services. Small but established diaspora community. Volume in thousands.
